newsitem.title: JAPAN: Honda develops new engine for power tools.
newsitem.headline: Honda develops new engine for power tools.

text.p: Honda Motor Co Ltd said on Tuesday it has launched a new ultra small four-stroke, general-purpose engine for hand-held power tools such as brush cutters and sprayers.
The new engines, the GX22 (22 cc) and GX31 (31 cc), feature a "rotary slinger pumping lubrication system" which means the engine is unaffected by the angle at which it is held.
Two-stroke engines hold a major share of the ultra small engine market because of lubrication problems. Conventional four-stroke engines cannot be operated when held upside-down.
It hopes to sell a total of 3.20 million general-purpose engines worldwide, including the GX22 and GX31, in calendar 1997, up from 2.42 million sold in 1996.
Honda will launch the GX40 (40 cc) and GX50 (50 cc) in November. It plans to sell one million units of the GX series engines and hand tools powered by the engines worldwide by 1998.
